Using the CLSI-based assays, several antifungal agents have been assessed for their activity against mycetoma causative agents. These include the polyene amphotericin B; the azoles ketoconazole, itraconazole, posaconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, isavuconazole and ravuconazole; the allylamine terbinafine; the pyrimidine analogue 5-flucytosine; the echinocandins caspofungin, anidulafunin and micafungin; and the orotomide olorofim (Table 3). Of these, the polyene amphotericin B forms pores in the ergosterol membrane, the azoles and the allylamines inhibit ergosterol synthesis at different stages, the pyrimidine analogue 5-flucytosine competes with pyrimide and the orotomide olorofim inhibits pyrimidine biosynthesis. The echinocandins inhibit 1,3-β-glucan synthesis (Figure 2). As can be seen in Table 3, the most common causative agent, M. mycetomatis, has low MICs for the azoles (median MIC50 0.03 µg/ml)
